section.title: Expressing obligation
section.sectiontitle: Use must / mustn't to talk about present and future strong obligations that come from the speaker.
section.text1a: I must go to bed early tonight.
section.text2a: We mustn't be late for the meeting.
section.sectiontitle2: Use have to / have got to to talk about present and future strong obligations that often come from outside the speaker.
section.text3a: We have to wear uniforms at our school.
section.text4a: You've got to show your ID before they will let you in this club.

section.title: Expressing obligation
section.sectiontitle: Use don't have to, don't need to or needn't to talk about a lack of obligation in the present or future.
section.text1a: You don't have to come shopping with me if you don't want to.
section.text2a: We don't need to check in until an hour before the plane leaves

section.title: Expressing obligation
section.sectiontitle: Use should (or ought to) to talk about obligations and duties in the future, present or past, and to give advice.
section.text1a: I really should go and visit my cousins in Wales.
section.text2a: You ought to take a bit more exercise.
section.sectiontitle2: Use should + have + past participle to criticise your own or other people's behaviour in the past.
section.text3a: I shouldn't have spoken to Brian like that.
section.text4a: She should have asked me before borrowing my car.

section.title: Expressing obligation
section.sectiontitle: Use supposed to to talk about what people have to do according to rules or about what is expected to happen.
section.text1a: You're supposed to wear a tie at work.
section.text2a: They weren't supposed to arrive until after 8 p.m.
section.sectiontitle2: Use had to to talk about past and reported obligations.
section.text3a: When I was at school we all had to stand up when the teacher came in.
section.text4a: Did you have to wait long for the bus this morning?
